question: Q. Who is the traditional author of the Gospel according to Matthew?
Q. What is the canonical setting of the Gospel of Matthew?
answer: A. Jesus’ earthly life, and was written in the late 50s to early 60s of the 1st Century A.D.

question: Q. What is the essential theme of the gospel of Matthew?
answer: A. That Jesus of Nazareth is the fulfillment of all the Scripture, and his coming ushers in the kingdom of heaven.

question: Q. According to Matthew’s genealogy, whose son is Jesus said to be?
Q. Which prophecy was fulfilled when Jesus was taken to Egypt as a baby by his father to flee from Herod’s decree?
Q. For how many days and nights did Jesus fast during his time in the wilderness?
Q. In Matthew 5, in what way does Jesus explain God’s common grace?
answer: A. He sends the sun and rain on the righteous and unrighteous. (5:45)

question: Q. What was Matthew’s profession when Jesus called him as a disciple?
Q. What does Jesus say is the unpardonable sin?
answer: A. Blasphemy against the Holy Spirit (Matt. 12:30-32)

question: Q. Which prophet spoke of the Messiah’s use of parables to blind seeing eyes?
Q. Apart from the Apostles, who was present with Jesus on the Mt. of Transfiguration?
Q. How many times does Jesus tell Peter that he is to forgive his brother?
Q. What was written above Jesus’ head on the Cross?
answer: A. This is Jesus, the king of the Jews (Matt. 27:37)

question: Q. In what hour did Jesus die, according to the Roman calendar in Matthew?
Q. On what mountain did Jesus predict the destruction of Jerusalem and teach on the end times?
Q. Who is the traditional author of the Gospel according to Mark?
answer: A. John Mark, and his source was possibly Peter

question: Q. What is the canonical setting of Mark?
answer: A. Jesus’ earthly life and ministry

question: Q. What is the date of the book of Matthew?
answer: A. Mid- to late 50s, maybe as late as mid- 60s, A.D.

question: Q. Who are the twelve disciples?
answer: A. Simon (Peter), James, John, Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James, Thaddeus, Simon, and Judas. (Mk. 3:16-19)

question: Q. Who were the Sons of Thunder?
Q. What did Jesus say was the problem with the disciples during the stormy sea that he calmed?
Q. What defiles a man?
answer: A. That which proceeds out of a man, ie: sins. (Mk. 7:20-21)

question: Q. What metaphor does Jesus use to describe the rich entering heaven?
answer: A. Like a camel going through the eye of a needle. (Mk. 10:23-27)

question: Q. What did blind Bartimaeus cry out to Jesus?
answer: A. “Son of David, have mercy on me.” (Mk. 10:47-48)

question: Q. What was the teaching Jesus gave as the reason he overturned tables in the temple court?
answer: A. Jesus was teaching them that they had turned the synagogue into a den of robbers, when the Lord’s house was meant to be a place of prayer for all the nations (Mk. 11:17)

question: Q. Where was Jesus when the alabaster vial of perfume was poured upon him?
answer: A. In Bethany at the house of Simon the leper (Mk. 14:3)

question: Q. Where did Jesus say he would meet the disciples after his resurrection?
Q. On what hour of the Roman day was Jesus crucified according to Mark?
Q. At what Roman hour did darkness fall on the earth during Jesus’ Passion according to Mark?
Q. Why were Mary and Mary going to the tomb where Jesus was laid on Sunday?
answer: A. To further anoint the body according to Jewish custom

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of the Gospel according to Luke?
answer: A. Luke the physician, who accompanied Paul on missionary journeys

question: Q. What is the date of the book of Luke?
Q. What were the temptations of Jesus in the wilderness and how did Jesus respond?
answer: A. Turn stones into bread, tempt God from the pinnacle of the temple, and to worship Satan in exchange for the kingdoms of the earth. (Lk. 4:1-13); Jesus responds by quoting from Deuteronomy

question: Q. In what district did Jesus begin his ministry?
Q. Jesus said that John the Baptist’s ministry was analogous to the ministry of what Old Testament prophet?
Q. What is the seed in the parable of the Sower and the seed?
Q. What happened with Jesus and the village of the Samaritans?
answer: A. They did not receive Jesus as he was traveling toward Jerusalem, which led to the sons of thunder asking Jesus to call down fire from heaven? (Lk. 9:51-56)

question: Q. In the parable of the Good Samaritan, what two people passed by the beaten man?
answer: A. A priest and a Levite (Lk. 10:30-32)

question: Q. What is the leaven of the Pharisees?
Q. What does Jesus say is lacking for people who are anxious?
Q. Which group of people did not believe in the resurrection of the dead?
Q. What title did the Sanhedrin ask if Jesus were claiming for himself?
Q. Who helped Jesus bear his Cross on the way to Golgotha?
Q. Where did the disciples see Jesus ascend into heaven?
Q. Who is the traditional author of the Gospel according to John?
Q. What is the date of the book of John?
Q. Where are the “I am” statements found?
answer: A. John 6:35 – I am the Bread of life; John 8:12 – I am the Light of the World; John 10:9 – I am the door (gate); John 10:11 – I am the good shepherd; John 11:25 – I am the resurrection and the life; John 14:6 – I am the way, and the truth, and the life; John 15:1 – I am the true vine; Before Abraham was born, I am (John 8:58)

question: Q. What are the Seven Great Signs?
answer: A. John 2:1-11 – Change water into wine; John 4:46-54 – Healing of the official’s son; John 5:1-15 – Healing the invalid (at the pool on the Sabbath); John 6:5-13 – Feeding the Five Thousand; John 6:16-21 – Walking on water; John 9:1-7 – Healing the man born blind; John 11:1-44 – Raising of Lazarus

question: Q. What act of service did Jesus perform in the upper room?
answer: A. He washed the feet of the disciples. (John 13:1-20)

question: Q. Who is the vine, who is the vinedresser, and who are the branches that remain?
Q. What does the Holy Spirit do in John 16?
answer: A. The HS convicts the world concerning sin, righteousness, and judgment. (16:8-11)

question: Q. Who does Jesus pray for in his high priestly prayer?
Q. Who is the traditional author of the book of Acts?
answer: A. Luke, the physician (same author as the Gospel of Luke)

question: Q. What is the period recorded for the book of Acts?
Q. What prophecy was fulfilled on the day of Pentecost according to Peter?
Q. Why was Peter, along with John, first placed on trial?
answer: A. For healing the lame beggar (Acts 3:1-4:12)

question: Q. Why were Ananias and Sapphira struck down?
answer: A. Because they lied to God, the Holy Spirit (Acts 5:1-11)

question: Q. What was Stephen’s office and why was he stoned?
answer: A. Deacon; because they were enraged by his sermon (Acts 6:5; 7:54-60)

question: Q. What is the sin of Simon?
answer: A. Attempt to buy spiritual gifts and power (Acts 8:18-25)

question: Q. What nationality was the eunuch that Philip evangelized on the desert road?
Q. What did Paul immediately start doing after his sight was healed?
answer: A. Proclaim that Jesus was the Son of God (Acts 9:20)

question: Q. Who was the first gentile in Caesarea that Peter evangelized?
Q. Who put James, the brother of John, to death and why?
answer: A. Herod the king, because it pleased the Jews (Acts 12:1-3)

question: Q. Why was the first ecumenical council in Jerusalem convened?
answer: A. To establish that the gentiles did not have to be circumcised according to Moses in order to be saved (Acts 15:1-30)

question: Q. How did the Bereans respond to Paul’s teaching concerning Jesus?
answer: A. They examined the scriptures and believed (Acts 17:10-15)

question: Q. What pagan altar inscription in Athens did Paul use to proclaim gentile ignorance of the true living God?
Q. What did Paul publicly say he was on trial for when he saw the Pharisees and Sadducees in the crowd at Jerusalem?
answer: A. For the hope of the resurrection of the dead (Acts 24:21)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of Romans?
Q. What are the major themes of Romans?
answer: A. The revelation of God’s judging and saving righteousness in the gospel of Jesus Christ; All people are sinners in need of salvation; The Righteousness of God; The Mosaic Law is good and holy but cannot take away sin; Through the righteousness of God, sin is judged, and salvation is provided; Jesus inaugurates a new age in redemptive history; Jesus’ atoning death is central to God’s plan of salvation; Justification is by faith alone; In Christ there is a sure and certain hope of future glory; Those who have died with Christ are made alive, given new life, by the Spirit; God is sovereign in salvation; God’s saving plan includes both Jews and Gentiles; The grace of the gospel calls Christians to holiness and service

question: Q. What is revealed from heaven against ungodliness?
Q. True circumcision, and thus to be truly Jewish, is a circumcision of what?
Q. When Paul explains how we are all under sin, what part of the Old Testament does he quote to explain, “There is none righteous”?
Q. The promise to Abraham came through what?
Q. By what are we justified?
Q. As Christ died for us while we were yet sinners, what should this teach us about God?
answer: A. It demonstrates his love toward us.

question: Q. If we are dead to sin, then we are alive to what?
Q. What are three key attributes of the Law that Paul uses to explain its function in Romans?
Q. What is the order, given by Paul, to the chain of salvation?
answer: A. Foreknowledge, predestination to the image of Christ, calling, justification, glorification

question: Q. Who does Paul refer to regarding God’s sovereignty in election?
Q. What paradox does Paul use to explain how a believer ought to live as a spiritual service of worship?
Q. List the gifts of the Spirit from Romans chapter twelve?
answer: A. Service, teaching, exhortation, giving, leading, and mercy (Rom. 12:7-8)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of 1 Corinthians?
Q. What is the date of 1 Corinthians?
Q. What is the major theme/concern of 1 Corinthians?
answer: A. The unity of Christ’s church; Erroneous practices; Sexual immorality; Legal action in pagan courts; Abuse of the Lord’s Supper; False teaching regarding the resurrection

question: Q. How does Paul address their problems?
answer: A. Paul calls them to repentance, remembering what Christ has done for his people.

question: Q. What is the source of division that Paul addresses in the first three chapters of 1 Corinthians?
answer: A. The Corinthian Church is divided over which preacher they like best (1:11; 3:1-23)

question: Q. In chapter 9, why did Paul surrender his right to be paid for his missionary work?
answer: A. So that an obstacle was not put in the way of the gospel

question: Q. Which chapter teaches about the Lord’s Supper?
Q. Which Church did the collection Paul took up help support?
Q. Who is the traditional author of 2 Corinthians?
Q. What is the main theme of 2 Corinthians?
answer: A. The relationship between suffering and the power of the Holy Spirit in Paul’s life, message, and ministry

question: Q. When was 2 Corinthians written?
Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 2 Corinthians?
answer: A. Many in Corinth doubted Paul’s apostolicity and ministry due to the suffering he experienced. Paul writes calling on the church in Corinth to repent.

question: Q. Summarize Paul’s missionary difficulties.
answer: A. Received forty lashes less one – five times (2 Cor. 11:24); Beaten with rods – three times (2 Cor. 11:25); Shipwrecked – three times (2 Cor. 11:25)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of Galatians?
Q. What is the canonical setting of Galatians?
Q. When was Galatians written?
Q. What is the main theme of Galatians?
answer: A. Christians are justified by faith alone and not by outward adherence to the ceremonies of the Mosaic Law.

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of the book of Galatians?
answer: A. Paul writes to correct false teachers who insisted Gentile Christians be circumcised.

question: Q. In Galatians 4:24, Sarah and Hagar are examples of?
Q. Who is the traditional author of Ephesians?
Q. When was Ephesians written?
Q. What is the purpose and occasion of Ephesians?
answer: A. There was no specific purpose to write Ephesians other than to inform the reader how Paul was doing in prison and to teach them about the redemptive work of Christ.

question: Q. What are the parts of the believer’s Armor of God in Ephesians 6?
answer: A. Belt of truth; Breastplate of righteousness; Shoes of the readiness given by the gospel of peace; Shield of faith; Helmet of salvation; Sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of Philippians?
answer: A. The Apostle Paul, written from jail.

question: Q. When was Philippians written?
Q. What is the main theme of Philippians?
answer: A. Encouragement; specifically to encourage Christians to live out their heavenly citizenship

question: Q. Whose conversion led to the founding of the church at Philippi?
Q. Philippians 2 teaches about what?
Q. Who is the traditional author of Colossians?
Q. When was Colossians written?
Q. What is the main theme of Colossians?
answer: A. Christ is Lord of Creation and Redemption and, therefore, the source of the Christian’s life

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of Colossians?
answer: A. Paul writes to correct of the false teaching in Colossae which he learned from Epaphras who traveled to Rome to meet with Paul.

question: Q. Who first brought the gospel to the Colossians?
Q. Colossians 1 ascribes the act of creation to which person of the Trinity?
answer: A. Christ, the second person of the Trinity (Col. 1:15-16)

question: Q. Who was with Paul when he wrote the letter to the Colossians?
Q. What is a reoccurring theme related to Christ?
Q. Who is the traditional author of 1 Thessalonians?
Q. When was 1 Thessalonians written?
Q. What is the main theme of 1 Thessalonians?
answer: A. The Second Coming of Jesus Christ

question: Q. What was the purpose and occasion of Paul’s writing 1 Thessalonians?
answer: A. To correct misunderstandings concerning the “Day of the Lord” and what happened to Christians who died before this day.

question: Q. How does Paul describe Christians who have died in 1 Thessalonians?
answer: A. He says they are asleep (1 Thess. 4:13)

question: Q. Who reported to Paul about the church in 1 Thessalonians?
Q. Who is the traditional author of 2 Thessalonians?
Q. When was 2 Thessalonians written?
Q. What is the main theme of 2 Thessalonians?
answer: A. The Second Coming of Christ (just like 1 Thess.)

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 2 Thessalonians?
answer: A. Paul writes to correct the idea that the “day of the Lord” had already come, because this mistaken idea had gained acceptance in Thessalonica.

question: Q. The Apostle Paul assures the Thessalonians, in his second letter to them, that their suffering and persecution would end when?
Q. What, according to Paul in 2 Thessalonians, must precede the “day of the Lord?”
answer: A. The rebellion and the man of lawlessness is revealed (2 Thess. 2:3)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of 1 Timothy?
Q. When was 1 Timothy written?
Q. What is the main theme of 1 Timothy?
answer: A. The gospel leads to holy living.

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 1 Timothy?
answer: A. Paul writes to inform Timothy about issues that arose within the church of Ephesus, specifically false teachers.

question: Q. According to 1Timothy, why is a recent convert not eligible to be a church officer?
answer: A. He might become conceited and fall into the hands of the devil (1 Tim. 3:6)

question: Q. In 1 Tim. 3, how does Paul describe the Church?
answer: A. As a pillar and buttress of the truth (1 Tim. 3:15b)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of 2 Timothy?
Q. When was 2 Timothy written?
Q. What is the main theme of 2 Timothy?
answer: A. Perseverance in spite of suffering

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 2 Timothy?
answer: A. Paul, near death, writes from prison in Rome to his close friend and co-worker, encouraging him to continue in faithfulness.

question: Q. In 2 Timothy, who does Paul commend for raising Timothy in the Christian faith?
answer: A. Lois (Timothy's grandmother) and Eunice (Timothy's mother)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of Titus?
Q. What is the main theme of Titus?
answer: A. The inseparable link between faith and practice

question: Q. When was Titus written?
Q. Why did Paul leave Titus in Crete?
answer: A. To appoint elders and bring order to the churches

question: Q. Why did Paul write the letter to Titus?
Q. What is the purpose and occasion of Titus?
answer: A. Paul writes to check on the churches he started in Crete and to correct the false teachers infecting the church in Crete.

question: Q. In Titus, according to Paul, what is the source of godliness for the Christian?
Q. How many times is the description “Savior” given to God or Christ in the book of Titus?
Q. Who is the traditional author of Philemon?
Q. When was Philemon written?
Q. What is the purpose/theme and occasion of Philemon?
answer: A. Paul writes to show the reconciliation that the gospel brings. He addresses Philemon in regard to his slave Onesimus.

question: Q. Why does Paul tell Philemon to be reconciled with Onesimus?
answer: A. He has become a Christian

question: Q. How does Paul instruct Philemon to receive back Onesimus?
answer: A. As, as a beloved brother (16) if he was receiving the apostle Paul himself (17)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of Hebrews?
Q. When was the book of Hebrews written?
answer: A. First century, most likely before A.D. 70

question: Q. What is the genre of the book of Hebrews?
Q. What was the purpose and occasion of Hebrews?
answer: A. The purpose is to exhort Christians to not forsake Christ; to encourage Christians to remain faithful in the midst of persecution.

question: Q. According to the book of Hebrews, what kind of rest remains for the people of God?
Q. Which Old Testament book does the author of Hebrews quote most frequently?
Q. How many “warning” passages are there in Hebrews?
Q. Which mysterious figure first seen in Genesis returns in Hebrews 7?
Q. What two Old Testament offices does Melchizedek hold in Hebrews?
Q. Hebrews calls the Old Testament Law and sacrifices what?
answer: A. Shadows and copies of the good things to come, of the heavenly realities (Heb. 9:23; 10:1)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of James?
Q. When was the book of James written?
Q. What is the purpose and occasion of James?
answer: A. James writes to show that the Christian faith must be lived out—faith without works is dead. Specifically, James addresses divisions, largely between the rich and the poor, that had arisen within the church to which he writes.

question: Q. To whom is the book of James addressed?
answer: A. The twelve tribes in the Dispersion (1:1)

question: Q. Which two Old Testament types of writing does James echo?
Q. Which part of the body does James strongly warn Christians must tame?
Q. Why does James say that Christians should “count it all joy” when they face trials of various kinds?
answer: A. Because the testing of faith produces steadfastness (James 1:2-4)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of 1 Peter?
Q. When was 1 Peter written?
Q. What is the main theme of 1 Peter?
answer: A. Perseverance in the midst of suffering—the way to glory

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 1 Peter?
answer: A. The purpose of 1 Peter is to encourage believers who are experiencing persecution and suffering to remain faithful. The occasion then would be the persecution and suffering that Christians experienced due to living as a Christian in the ancient world (not an Empire wide, official persecution of Christians as some think).

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of 2 Peter?
Q. When was 2 Peter written?
Q. What is the main theme of 2 Peter?
answer: A. Grace truly transforms lives even when faced with opposition

question: Q. What opposition were the original readers of 2 Peter facing?
Q. What does Peter say is “more sure” than even being an eyewitness of the Transfiguration?
Q. What does 2 Peter say about Paul’s writing?
answer: A. Some of the things Paul teaches are hard to understand.

question: Q. What is the canonical setting of 1 John?
answer: A. New Testament Church/ Apostolic Age

question: Q. When was 1 John written?
answer: A. No later than the A.D. 90s

question: Q. What is the main theme of 1 John?
answer: A. Living out our fellowship with God and one another

question: Q. What three themes does John employ to describe Christian fellowship?
answer: A. God is light, love, and life.

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 1 John?
answer: A. John writes to show that Christ’s work is finished and the fellowship it has established between the Christian and God and between fellow Christians. This fellowship is built on truth and love. John writes this letter due to the factions that arose within the church.

question: Q. When was 2 John written?
Q. What is the main theme of 2 John?
answer: A. The balance of love and truth in the Christian life

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 2 John?
answer: A. John wrote this letter to encourage Christians to love one another and watch out for false teachers who had departed from the truth. The presence of false teachers was the occasion that led to John writing this letter.

question: Q. How does John refer to himself in 2 John?
Q. When was 3 John written?
Q. What is the main theme of 3 John?
answer: A. Faithfulness in the face of opposition

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of 3 John?
answer: A. To encourage Gaius to remain faithful in spite of the opposition he is facing at the hands of Diotrephes.

question: Q. How does John refer to himself in 3 John?
Q. In 3 John, what is Diotrephes doing that causes trouble?
answer: A. He is putting himself first and not acknowledging the leader’s authority (v. 9)

question: Q. Why is Gaius commissioned in 3 John?
answer: A. His support of fellow Christian workmen (v.5)

question: Q. Who is the traditional author of Revelation?
Q. When was Revelation written?
Q. Where did John write Revelation from?
Q. What is the genre of Revelation?
Q. What is the main theme of Revelation?
answer: A. The spiritual war in which the church is engaged and Christ’s victory

question: Q. What is the purpose and occasion of Revelation?
answer: A. The purpose is to strengthen the seven churches who represent all of Christ’s churches; the occasion is false teaching, persecution, heresy, beguiling affluence.

question: Q. What does the beast in Revelation represent?
answer: A. Intimidating violence against the church

question: Q. What does the false prophet in Revelation represent?
Q. What does the prostitute in Revelation represent?
Q. What are the three major eschatological positions that all appeal to the book of Revelation for support?
Q. Revelation reveals that God is gathering to himself a people from where?
answer: A. From every tribe, language, people and nation (Rev. 5:9)

question: Q. Summarize the circumstances in each of the seven churches are addressed in Rev. 2-3?
answer:
A. Ephesus – They have abandoned their first love (Rev. 2:4);
Smyrna – Jesus has nothing against them;
Pergamum – Some hold to the teaching of Balaam and some also hold to the teaching of the Nicolaitans (Rev. 2:14-15);
Thyatira – They tolerate the woman called Jezebel (Rev. 2:20);
Sardis – They are dead in spite of their works (Rev. 3:1);
Philadelphia – Jesus has nothing against them;
Laodicea – They are lukewarm (Rev. 3:15)

question: Q. What are the four major schools of interpretation regarding the book of Revelation?
Q. In Revelation 1, the Lord God calls himself?
Q. In the book of Revelation, how many seals does the Lamb open?
Q. What is the light source of the New Jerusalem?
Q. When John sees the holy city, the New Jerusalem, how does it establish itself?
answer: A. It comes down out of heaven (Rev. 21:2)

question: Q. What flows from the throne of God in the New Heavens and New Earth?
